tossups.question: Adherents of this religion meet in groups called namahattas. This movement’s official newsletter is called “Back to Godhead,” and it started the largest vegetarian charity, Food for Life. This religion belongs to the Gaudiya Vaishnava branch, and its name comes from the first two words of the (*) Maha Mantra. This religion was founded by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada and its members are known for their shaved heads, sometimes with a topknot. This religion is monotheistic and promotes the use of bhakti yoga towards the “all-attractive one,” an avatar of Vishnu who is the masculine counterpart of Radha. For 10 points, name this Western-friendly branch of Hinduism that was featured in a Beatles song.
tossups.answer: Hare Krishna Movement or ISKCON or International Society for Krishna Consciousness <Mathew>
tossups.answer_formatted: Hare Krishna Movement or ISKCON or International Society for Krishna Consciousness <Mathew>
acceptable: Hare Krishna Movement or ISKCON or International Society for Krishna Consciousness <Mathew>
Hare Krishna Movement or ISKCON or International Society for Krishna Consciousness <Mathew>

tossups.question: This man retreated from Russia after an icon called the Theotokos of Vladimir was brought to Moscow, causing one ruler to build the Sretensky Monastery in relief. Henry III of Castile sent a famous embassy to this man’s capital, after which he referred to Henry as “his very own son.” This leader won the Battle of the Kondurcha River before winning another battle on the (*) Terek River to defeat Tokhtamysh. He set some camels on fire in a victory over the Tughluq dynasty and also captured Bayezid I at the Battle of Ankara. This grandfather of Ulugh Beg died before carrying out his plan to invade Ming China. He legendarily became crippled after a shepherd shot him for trying to steal a sheep. For 10 points, name this 14th-century conqueror of Central Asia.

Vaska’s complex contains two atoms of this element bonded to iridium, and the nucleophilic addition of this element to a carbonyl carbon begins the Perkow reaction. This element is bonded to three alkyl groups in one of the reactants in the Michaelis-Arbuzov reaction, and this element binds to an azide in the Staudinger reaction. This element is found double-bonded to an oxygen in the nerve agent sarin, and overexposure to this element can cause necrosis of the (*) jaw. The radioactive 32-isotope of this element is used in a Northern blot, and a ylide of this element is reacted to form an alkene in the Wittig reaction. An acid of named for this element has three Ka values, because the polyatomic ion containing this element and oxygen has a -3 charge. This element comes in black, violet, red, and white allotropes. For 10 points, name this element with atomic number 15 and symbol P.

A man in this play responds “come sit on me” after he is called a “join’d stool.” One character in this play is persuaded to make the claim that the sun is the moon. This play begins with an introduction involving a nobleman and a drunk audience member named (*) Christopher Sly, who is tricked into thinking he is part of the nobility. In Act III of this play, two characters try to woo a woman by disguising themselves as a Latin teacher and a music teacher. That woman in this play is Bianca, the younger daughter of Baptista Minola, who eventually marries Lucentio in secret. For 10 points, name this Shakespeare play centered on the courtship of Petruchio and the title woman, Katherina.

This man showed Mary and Jesus flanked by the titular flower-holding figures in his Madonna with Lilies and Eight Angels. Two frescoes by this man depicting the Youth of Moses and the Temptations of Jesus are located on opposite walls in the Sistine Chapel. This man’s only signed work includes twelve angels in the colors of faith, hope and charity and is his (*) Mystical Nativity, while Lucrezia Tornabuoni is depicted as the Virgin Mary in his Madonna of the Magnificat. Chloris and Zephyrus appear in a pair of paintings by this artist, one of which depicts them dancing in an orange grove and another of which shows them blowing the titular goddess from a scallop shell. For 10 points, name this Italian Renaissance artist of The Birth of Venus and Primavera.

In Selenomonas, these structures characteristically arrange themselves in a fascicle. Opisthokonts have these structures on the posterior rather than the anterior side. Chytridiomycota are the only members of their kingdom to possess these structures, and the arrangement of these structures can be described as lophotrichous or monotrichous. These structures are driven by a Mot complex and can use the protein FliG to (*) change direction. These structures have L, P, and MS rings in Gram-negative bacteria, and they contain a hook, rod, filament, and basal body. The axonemes of these structures have microtubules in a nine plus two arrangement, and they use dynein and ATP to power their whipping motion. For 10 points, name these locomotive structures found in sperm cells that beat differently from cilia.

A character in this work removes the eye of a man who frequently uses a pair of brass knuckles. That character later attempts suicide after a conversation with Mr. Faisal and the main character, who writes a story in which a man kills his wife and cries tears of pearls. Many years after fleeing to (*) San Francisco with his father, the protagonist returns to his home country with the help of Rahim Khan. The protagonist of this novel rescues the orphan Sohrab from a pedophile and adopts him. The pivotal scene in this novel takes place when the protagonist witnesses the Hazara boy Hassan being raped. For 10 points, name this novel, titled after the task Hassan performs for Amir after Kabul’s winter tournament, by Khaled Hosseini.

One piece for this instrument was written for Joseph de Pasquale by Walter Piston. Tibor Serly completed one piece for this instrument which was commissioned and premiered by William Primrose. One piece for this instrument was composed in six hours after the death of George V. William Walton’s concerto for this instrument is dedicated “to Christabel” and was written for Lionel Tertis. Der (*) Schwanendreher was written as a concerto for this instrument by Paul Hindemith, and it is also the soloist in his Trauermusik. It’s not the violin, but Niccolo Paganini commissioned a piece featuring this instrument whose movements include “March of the Pilgrims” and “Orgy of the Brigands”. For 10 points, name this instrument that plays the solo in Hector Berlioz’s Harold in Italy.

This name is given to a river that contains the Da Wan, Nansha, and Madushan dams, and another dam on that river formed the Thac Ba Lake. Another river with this name is formed at the confluence of the Otter Tail and Bois de Sioux rivers, while yet another arises from a namesake North Fork and the Prairie Dog Town Fork. Cities like Grand Forks and (*) Fargo are on the banks of one river with this name; another river with this name names a Manitoba colony in which a rebellion was led by Louis Riel. The largest river given this name marked the US-Spain boundary defined by the Adams-Onis Treaty. For 10 points, give this name of a river in Vietnam and two in North America, one of which forms the border of Texas and Oklahoma.

This event was originally held at Worple Road before it moved to Church Road, its modern location, in 1922. People gather on Aorangi Terrace to watch this event, and two lines of a Rudyard Kipling poem are inscribed above the entrance to a building used for this event. Spencer Gore won the inaugural version of this event in 1877, and modern winners of this event receive the Challenge Cup. One man famously yelled “You cannot be (*) serious!” while participating in this event, and this event is traditionally suspended on its Middle Sunday. In 2001, wildcard Goran Ivanišević won this event despite being ranked 125th in the world. This event is closely associated with strawberries and cream, and in the most recent edition of this event, a record eighth title was won by Roger Federer. For 10 points, name this Grand Slam tournament in England, the only tennis major currently played on grass.

One battle between two groups of these people was fought over a poorly distributed fish harvest. The earliest known settlement of these people is the archaeological site of Wairau Bar. Members of this ethnic group killed and ate about 70 Europeans in the Boyd massacre. Frederick Maning helped mediate several disputes between Western colonists and these people. These people fought the (*) Flagstaff War against the British under the leadership of Hone Heke, who had earlier fought in the Musket Wars. This group massacred the Moriori people, former members of this group who migrated to the Chatham Islands. These people, who still perform the haka dance, were persuaded to sign the Treaty of Waitangi with William Hobson. For 10 points, name these indigenous people of New Zealand.

This figure once made a man appear to look like another named Gorlois so he could sleep with Igraine and conceive a child. As a child, this figure was brought to, and nearly sacrificed by, Vortigern, after which this figure solved Vortigern’s problem of a constantly collapsing castle by revealing that the castle was built upon a pool that contained two sleeping dragons, one red and one white, which frequently fought. After Vortigern’s death, this figure oversaw the erection of (*) Stonehenge. One night, this figure witnessed the tail of a comet cause the sky to light up in the shape of a dragon and, as a result, told Uther that his brother was dead and that he was king. For ten points, name this designer of the round table and creator of the test of the sword in the stone, a trusted advisor to King Arthur and famous magician.

This movie director’s comic-book adaptations include Blade II and another movie centered around a demon-like superhero that fights Nazis. That movie is Hellboy. One of this director’s Spanish-language movies is The Devil’s Backbone, and another of his Spanish-language films follows Ofelia and a faun in Pan’s (*) Labyrinth. This director’s most recent movie follows a mute laboratory janitor as she protects a creature called the “Asset” and it won the Golden Lion in 2017. That movie is The Shape of Water. Another of this director’s monster-obsessed films centers around the fight between kaijus and jaegers in Pacific Rim. For ten points, identify this Mexican director who is part of the “Three Amigos of Cinema,” along with Alfonso Cuarón and Alejandro González Iñárritu.

The coefficient of restitution for an object is equal to this power of the ratio of the initial potential energy to the final potential energy. In Planck units, electric charge equals Planck charge times the fine-structure constant to this power, and the second of Mersenne’s laws states that the fundamental frequency is proportional to this power of the stretching force. After falling for a height h near the surface of the Earth, an object that fell from rest will have velocity equal to this power of (*) 2gh. At constant inductance, the potential energy stored in an inductor will be equal to this number times inductance times current squared; similarly, the potential energy in a spring equals this number times the spring constant times displacement squared. At small angles, the period of a pendulum is proportional to its length raised to this power. A displacement of 3 meters in 6 seconds gives, for 10 points, what average velocity?

In one novel named for this substance, two Siamese princes search a hill for a jade ring with two Yakshas carved onto it and earlier in that novel the protagonist and his friend witness a dead dog clogging a waterfall. In another novel named for this substance, a farmer is said to have named a restaurant for his mistress then made his wife run it after the mistress ran away. Earlier in that work, the protagonist witnesses a girl jump to her death from a (*) burning silkworm warehouse, after which he feels the “Milky Way flow inside him.” That novel centers on the affair between the geisha Komako and the ballet expert Shimamura. For 10 points name this substance whose Spring type titles a Mishima novel and whose Country titles a Kawabata novel.

One king of this country ordered the planting of a large pine forest near its city of Leiria. Ali ibn Yusuf was defeated at the Battle of Ourique by a man from this country who was later crowned Afonso I. This nation was ruled for 46 years by a monarch known as the Farmer King, Denis. One explorer from this country saw his brother Paulo die on an expedition during which the cartographer Ibn Majid showed him the direction of (*) monsoon winds. John I founded this nation’s second royal dynasty, the House of Aviz, which was succeeded by the House of Braganza. This country, whose capital suffered a devastating earthquake in 1755, divided its claims in the Americas with Spain in the Treaty of Tordesillas. For 10 points, name this country home to Vasco da Gama, the easternmost nation on the Iberian Peninsula.

Seleucus of Seleucia was the first person to correctly theorize the cause of these phenomena. The M2 constituent is the largest constituent of these phenomena, and these phenomena are maximized at the antipodal point. The forces associated with these phenomena have an inverse cubic relationship with distance. Terms such as the partial derivative of g zeta plus U with respect to lambda appear in a set of (*) three partial differential equations to model these phenomena; those equations were formulated by Laplace. At amphidromic points, these phenomena have zero amplitude. These phenomena occur in semi-diurnal and diurnal forms, the former of which occurs two times in its high type and two times in its low type per day. When these phenomena are at their weakest, they are called “neap.” For 10 points, name these rises and falls in the sea level, which on Earth, are caused by the gravitational forces of the Moon and the Sun.

This man escaped from prison thanks to the efforts of Angelica Schuyler Church, but was promptly recaptured after getting lost. This man became known as “fearsome horseman” among the Oneida after recruiting them to his side in one conflict. In this man’s first command, 350 of his soldiers defeated 400 Hessians at the Battle of Gloucester. James Grant failed to encircle a smaller force led by this general at the Battle of Barren Hill. This man headed the (*) National Guard during the deposition of Charles X; later, he drafted the Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen and presented it to the National Assembly in 1789. This man linked up with George Washington to defeat Cornwallis at Yorktown, and he was wounded in the leg at the Battle of Brandywine. For 10 points, name this French nobleman who served in the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War.

This thinker argued that knowledge is sufficient but limited with a metaphor of a sailor who cannot measure the depth of the sea. In one thought experiment, this thinker considered a prince and a cobbler who switch bodies and in another thought experiment, this thinker considered a man who was locked in a room that he did not want to leave. In another work, this thinker coined the term “sortal” to describe identity and change and in another work he argued to extend the title concept to everyone (*) except Catholics and Atheists. In another work, this thinker argued that people are born lacking inherent qualities, a term he called “tabula rasa”. For ten points name this philosopher who wrote “A Letter Concerning Toleration” and An Essay Concerning Human Understanding.

One of this man’s title characters is thrilled to find out that he has been speaking prose his entire life; that man later undergoes a fake ceremony to make him a Turkish nobleman in a play about the social climber Jourdain. This author of The Bourgeois Gentleman created a character who steals a box of incriminating letters which causes Monsieur Loyal to evict his victim’s family. This man died on stage while playing one of his characters who tries to convince his daughter (*) Cleante to marry Dr. Thomas Diaforious so he can get free medical treatment - that man is Argan. He also wrote about a hypocritical religious man who tries to seduce Elmire and fools Orgon. For 10 points, name this French playwright of The Imaginary Invalid and Tartuffe.

bonuses.leadin: This writer described the relationship between Henry and Annie in his play The Real Thing. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Czech-British playwright of the Coast of Utopia trilogy and Arcadia.
This Stoppard play centers on the relationship between the playwright Henry and the actress Annie, who tries to free the Scottish soldier Brodie from prison.
Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are characters from this Shakespeare play about a titular Danish prince.

bonuses.leadin: One function named for this letter is defined for all complex numbers, except zero and the negative integers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this letter, which names an extension of the factorial function.
Gamma also names a constant approximately equal to 0.577, named for this man and Mascheroni.
Euler was a mathematician from this country. A problem he solved, asking for the sum of the reciprocals of all positive squares, is named for a city in this country.

bonuses.leadin: This man described a tyranny led by the “Oligarchy” in his dystopian novel The Iron Heel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of The Call of the Wild and White Fang.
The subordinate relationship between the literary critic Humphrey Van Weyden and an amoral naval captain named Larsen is described in this London novel.
In this London short story, an unnamed tobacco-chewing protagonist ventures out into the Yukon with his dog. He dies after thrice failing to perform the titular action.

bonuses.leadin: Name some manipulative mythological creatures. For 10 points each:
parts: These tricky beings are often described as being made of smokeless fire and while often wild and malevolent, were controlled and used by Solomon to build the First Temple in the Quran.
These tiny mischievous creatures spend most of their time mending shoes. If they are captured by a human, the sometimes grant three wishes in order to escape, usually relating to a pot of gold.
Another famous manipulator, Māui failed to complete his last trick because he was killed inside the vagina of Hine-nui-te-pō while in the form of this pinkish animal.

bonuses.leadin: In this province, Pierre Laporte was kidnapped and killed by the paramilitary group FLQ. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this province of Canada, better known for its mostly French-speaking population.

To get Quebec to approve the 1982 Canadian constitution, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney pushed for ratification of this agreement. It strengthened the powers of the provinces and declared Quebec a “distinct society.”
This man, Mulroney’s predecessor as prime minister, was an early opponent of the Meech Lake Accord. His son is the current prime minister of Canada.

bonuses.leadin: Stories like “A Simple Heart” and “Saint Julian the Hospitaller” make up this author’s Three Tales. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French author, who described the title character’s suicide by arsenic in Madame Bovary.
Frederic Moreau meets the banker Dambreuse starts a relationship with the prostitute Rosanette in this Flaubert novel, set during the Revolution of 1848.

In Sentimental Education, parallel lines symbolize Frederic’s love for this woman, who was modeled after the wife of the publisher Charles Schlesinger. She leaves for Rome with her husband at the end of the novel.

bonuses.leadin: One section of this work describes how the central culture made for ideal occupied people. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this work that describes Japanese culture during the occupation following World War II. It describes the repayment of debts and ritual suicides and has been heavily criticized by Takeo Doi.
The Chrysanthemum and the Sword was written by this American anthropologist. In her book Patterns of Culture, she described culture as “personality writ large.”
Benedict’s mentor was this Columbia professor who wrote The Mind of Primitive Man.

bonuses.leadin: The Lennard-Jones potential predicts that the potential energy of these interactions is proportional to the negative sixth power of distance. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these weak intermolecular forces that exist between induced dipoles, named for a German scientist.
Another intermolecular force, a hydrogen bond, can create this system of two water molecules bound by a hydrogen bond. It is the simplest water cluster.
Two glucose molecules can react to form this dimer and water. This reducing sugar is a disaccharide with eight free hydroxyl groups.

bonuses.leadin: Archaeologists divided this site into the Hill Complex, Valley Complex, and Great Enclosure. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ancient city built by the ancestral Shona people, the most prominent ruin in a namesake southern African country.
Great Zimbabwe is most famous for its soapstone carvings of these animals, one of which appears on Zimbabwe’s national flag.

Several of the soapstone bird carvings from Great Zimbabwe were originally sold to this man, who founded the De Beers diamond company and planned the Cape to Cairo Railway. The country of Zimbabwe was formerly named after him.

bonuses.leadin: Judaism and Islam are classified as religions that follow the god of this patriarch. For 10 points each,
answers: Abraham [or Avraham or Abram or Avram or Ibrahim]
names of God [or clear knowledge equivalents]
parts: Name this figure, the father of Ishmael and husband of Sarah.
In Judaism, this concept includes the Tetragrammaton, and vowels are often not used while writing this down. Some of these in Islam include al-Quddus and al-Malik.
In the Tanakh, this angel explains visions to Daniel. This archangel transmitted the Quran from Allah to Muhammad.

bonuses.leadin: This man founded the magazine Camera Work and created the art gallery 291. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Photo-Secessionist photographer whose works include Winter – Fifth Avenue and The Terminal.
This most famous photograph by Stieglitz depicts several lower-class men and women on a ship going from New York to Bremen.
In 1936, Stieglitz hosted one of the first exhibitions of work by this other American photographer. He photographed Half Dome and several other landmarks in Yosemite National Park.

bonuses.leadin: This protein helps to arrest the cell at the G1 to S checkpoint. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this “guardian angel of the genome.” Elephants notably have 20 copies of the gene that encodes for this protein, making them highly unlikely to get cancer.
This virus creates a protein called E6 which suppresses p53. Gardasil can help prevent infection by this virus. A non-cancerous strain of this virus can cause plantar warts.
The gene that encodes for p53 is located on this chromosome. The gene that encodes for gamma-actin is also located on this chromosome.

bonuses.leadin: One member of this family hires the agricultural expert Napoleon Letsitsi to teach farming techniques. For 10 points each:
answers: Ah, But Your Land is Beautiful <Sivakumar>
parts: Name this family, one of whose members is killed by Absalom Kumalo.
The Jarvis family appears in Cry, the Beloved Country, a work by this South African author.
This other anti-apartheid novel by Paton includes sections like “The Defiance Campaign” and “Into the Golden Age”. It fictionalizes his years working as a political activist.
acceptable: Ah, But Your Land is Beautiful <Sivakumar>
Ah, But Your Land is Beautiful <Sivakumar>

bonuses.leadin: Talal Asad wrote The Idea of an Anthropology of (this religion) and Basil Matthews wrote “Young (this religion) On Trek.” For 10 points each:
answers: Abū Ḥāmid Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad al-Ghazālī
Averroes (or Abū l-Walīd Muḥammad Ibn ʾAḥmad Ibn Rushd) <McLain>
parts: Name this religion that Clifford Geertz “Observed” in Indonesia and Morocco. The differences in the two regions practice of this religion led Geertz to use the terms “religious” and “religious minded” to distinguish them.
This Persian Islamic mystic claimed that the heart of man is a mirror designed to reflect God’s light. He argued against the use of Avicennian philosophy in his The Incoherence of Philosophers.

This other Islamic thinker responded to al-Ghazali in The Incoherence of the Incoherence. In other works, he made the idea of double truth regarding religion and philosophy and he developed the spiritualization theory of memory.
acceptable: Abū Ḥāmid Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad al-Ghazālī
Abū Ḥāmid Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad al-Ghazālī
metadata: or Abū l-Walīd Muḥammad Ibn ʾAḥmad Ibn Rushd

bonuses.leadin: This piece uses a 5/8 motif to represent the movement of oars. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this piece, which depicts souls being rowed to the titular location. It was inspired by a painting of the same name which includes several cypress trees.
Isle of the Dead was written by this Russian composer, whose more famous works include four difficult piano concertos and Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini.

Arnold Bocklin, who painting Isle of the Dead inspired Rachmaninoff, also created a self-portrait with death playing this instrument. Notable players of this instrument include Joshua Bell and Itzhak Perlman.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about American pioneers in women’s rights. For 10 points each:
parts: This Quaker, renowned for her speaking ability, helped organize the Seneca Falls convention along with Elizabeth Cady Stanton.
This woman was arrested after attempting to vote in the 1872 presidential election. She is now depicted on the one-dollar coin.
In 1913, organizers of a women’s suffrage march tried to exclude this journalist from marching because she was black. She is better known for documenting lynchings in the American South.

bonuses.leadin: According to Paschen's Law, this quantity is proportional to gas pressure times the distance between electrodes. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this value, which is about three times ten to the sixth volts per meter for air.
The “avalanche” type of these devices operates in the reserve direction if the reverse bias voltage is greater than the breakdown voltage. These devices conduct current in only one direction.
This type of diode is different from an avalanche diode because it will stop conducting if the reverse bias voltage drops below the breakdown voltage.

bonuses.leadin: The first of these conflicts began with the Battle of Bov and was ended by the London Protocol. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these conflicts, which erupted over a disputed territory between Germany and Denmark.
The Second Schleswig War was instigated by this German chancellor, who pursued the policy of Kulturkampf and delivered the Blood and Iron speech.
A treaty signed in this city ended the Schleswig Wars. An earlier conference in this city revoked French conquests and later helped end the Hundred Days.

bonuses.leadin: This painting was the center panel of a commission that included The Frontier of Ethical Evolution and The Frontier of Material Development. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this painting, which used “elongated ellipses” to depict the discoveries of astronomy and biology. It also included an armless statue of Jupiter and a headless statue of Caesar.
Man at the Crossroads was later recreated as Man, Controller of the Universe by this artist, who was married to Frida Kahlo.
This other Mexican muralist painted Man of Fire for the Cabañas Hospice. He included Gods of the Modern World and Hispano-America in his cycle Epic of American Civilization.

bonuses.leadin: In February 2017, this leader admitted he had “turned his back” on pursuing election reform. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Liberal prime minister of Canada who succeeded Stephen Harper.
Trudeau was ruled to have violated the Conflict of Interest Act over a vacation with Aga Khan IV, the current leader of the Nizari Ismaili branch of this religion.
This liberal opposition party in Canada elected Jagmeet Singh, the first Sikh leader of a major Canadian political party.
